info.game_comments:
2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 16.

(Jimmy: We're stepping out and into Manhattan's famous 21 Club. Do join us for clues on Jeopardy!, next!)

(1, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from a  table at 21, holding a cocktail.)  Cosmo in hand & wearing my Manolos, I'm at the table at 21 where this comedy's Carrie dined with Mr. Big

(2, 1).clue: History:Herman's Hermits hit No. 1 in 1965 singing "I'm" this man, "I Am"

(3, 1).clue: "You teach and admonish rebels to no purpose, and in vain you cast pearls of divine eloquence before" these

(5, 1).clue: The green triangle on Sudan's flag represents this religion

(6, 1).clue: You've got the right profile if you know it's over 5,600 feet high in the Black Hills

(1, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from a lectern at 21.)  "A lot of people still don't really know who I am", said this Massachusetts senator at an April 2004 fundraiser at 21

(2, 2).clue: Shop:In '66 the Rolling Stones saw "a red door" & wanted to perform this title deed

(3, 2).clue: "It was your command, not love of God, which made me take" this, meaning to become a nun

(5, 2).clue: This amusement park chain is named for the multiple banners that once flew over Texas

(1, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from behind the bar at 21.)  Among the mementos at 21 is a gift, donated by John F. Kennedy, of the  model that represents this boat

(2, 3).clue: Math:This group hit No. 1 with "You're Once, Twice, Three Times A Lady"

(3, 3).clue: "No one would lay on an ass a burden suitable for" this huge mammal

(5, 3).clue: This geographic feature on Nebraska's state flag bears the name of another state

(6, 3).clue: Won an acting Oscar in 1931 for "A Free Soul"

(1, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from a booth at 21.)  In 1944, the year they made "To Have and Have Not", these two superstars got engaged right here, at table 30

(2, 4).clue: Gym:Olivia Newton-John topped the charts for 10 weeks with this 1981 1-word-title tune

(3, 4).clue: "The punishment you suffered would have been proper vengeance for men caught" committing this, a biblical no-no

(5, 4).clue: This grizzly-bannered nation was declared in California in 1846

(6, 4).clue: This tree is also called a buttonwood & a buttonball

(1, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from a booth in the wine cellar  at 21.)  During Prohibition this mayor, called "Gentleman Jimmy", had his own booth here at 21 in the secret wine cellar the feds never found

(2, 5).clue: Bad English:That group made its Top 40 debut in '89 with "When I See You" do this

(3, 5).clue: "But if I lose you, what is left for me to hope for?  What reason for continuing on life's" this, a sacred journey

(5, 5).clue: The colors on this Low Country's flag came from the coat of arms of the province of Brabant

(6, 5).clue: Paired with Lawrence in the name of a California nuclear weapons lab

(1, 1).clue: The largest horde this Mongol leader who died in 1227 ever assembled was less than 240,000 men

(2, 1).clue: He played Tony Spampatta in the 1991 TV movie "N.Y.P.D. Mounted" before getting "Blue" in '93

(3, 1).clue: The charcoal used in barbecues is usually sold in this form, a French diminutive

(4, 1).clue: 3-letter word for any of the small coral islets off the tip of Florida

(5, 1).clue: An early 1730s work by Canaletto shows this canal city's "Quay of the Piazzetta"

(6, 1).clue: Poetic title of M. Scott Peck's 1978 self-help bestseller

(1, 2).clue: On Nov. 8, 2004 U.S. & Iraqi forces entered this Sunni city of 300,000 beginning a fierce battle

(2, 2).clue: Heeey maaan, he was soooo groovy playing Billy in "Easy Rider", man

(3, 2).clue: A W-shaped rack was created & named for these "anatomical" taste treats

(4, 2).clue: From the French for "throat", it's a narrow steep-walled canyon

(5, 2).clue: In "The Story of Painting" Sister Wendy says, "He is much more than a painter of the fair and fat"

(6, 2).clue: 2-word descriptive term for an island group of the eastern West Indies

(1, 3).clue: In 774 this Frank took the crown of Desiderius, the last king of the Lombards

(2, 3).clue: You could say the blushing bride seen here was on the rebound

(3, 3).clue: In 1793 the laying of the cornerstone of this D.C. building was celebrated by barbecuing a 500-pound ox

(4, 3).clue: 5-letter term for a territory ruled by a duke

(5, 3).clue: There are 2 versions of John Singleton Copley's "Watson and" this sea predator in U.S. galleries

(6, 3).clue: She explored the inner workings of feminine identity in novels like "The Golden Notebook"

(1, 4).clue: It declared its independence in January of 1822 at Epidauros but still had to fight for 7 years

(2, 4).clue: This Oakland A's Hall of Famer is the only pitcher with 100 complete games & 100 saves (& he threw a no-hitter too!)

(3, 4).clue: George Stephen invented the Weber grill using the bottom of one of these items found in harbors

(4, 4).clue: This term for an administrative district in England has largely been replaced by county

(5, 4).clue: For your information, no, your six-year-old could not make paintings just like this man's 1952 "Convergence"

(6, 4).clue: His company went bankrupt trying to build the Panama Canal

(1, 5).clue: A participant in WWI's First Battle of the Marne was the BEF, short for this

(2, 5).clue: This actor can do it all; he can sell you insurance as the Allstate spokesman, or run the country as president on "24"

(3, 5).clue: Hardwoods work best for this type of cooking that some purists call the only real type of barbecue

(4, 5).clue: It's a bay formed by a bend in a coastline, like the one "of Benin"

(5, 5).clue: Victorine Meurent, his favorite model, is the nude in his "Le dejeuner sur l'herbe"

(0, 0).clue: "Grand Master Villiers de l'Isle d'Adam had" this made "by Turkish slaves in the castle of St. Angelo"
